direction.raw_text: (V.O.) You have a choice in this world, I believe, about how to tell sad stories.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a SERIES OF QUICK IMAGES: - Hazel and the BOY we will come to know as AUGUSTUS "GUS" WATERS (17) at an outdoor restaurant in some magical place. [They look very much like the perfect Hollywood couple.]
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) On the one hand, you can sugar coat - the way they do in movies and romance novels. - "Perfect" Hazel and "Perfect" Gus sit on a BENCH overlooking an incredible seascape in some foreign country. She rests her head on his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Where villains are vanquished and... heroes are born and... - "Perfect" Hazel and "Perfect" Gus kiss in a dark room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) ... beautiful people learn beautiful lessons... - "Perfect" Hazel and "Perfect" Gus fall onto a bed together. They look deep into one another's eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) ... and nothing is too messed up that can't be fixed with an apology and a Peter Gabriel song.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel on the grass, still watching the stars. Were those dreams or were they memories? Still unclear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) I like that way as much as the next girl, believe me. It's just not the truth. Hazel closes her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) This is the truth. And EVERYTHING GOES BLACK. We HEAR:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The real Hazel is no less beautiful than the one we just saw.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Late in the Winter of my 17th year... There are, however, some key and obvious differences. First, you'll notice the OXYGEN TUBE in her nostrils which help her to breathe. Second, you'll notice her hair - which we couldn't see in the grass. It's much shorter than the "Perfect" version, the result of someone whose head was completely shaved a few years before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) ... my mother decided I was depressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not depressed. Hazel's legs dangle over the side of an exam table. Her mother FRANNIE (early 40s, younger than she feels) explains to the DOCTOR:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... she eats like a bird. She barely leaves the house,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not depressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... she reads the same book over and over...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's depressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not depressed! Off her look, CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: which play over:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The booklets and web sites always list depression as a side effect of cancer... - A SHOPPING MALL. Filled with TEENAGE GIRLS - gossipping, laughing - being teenage girls, basically. And here's Hazel. With her Mom. And her oxygen tank. Just another day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Depression's not a side effect of cancer... - HAZEL'S LIVING ROOM. She sits watching game shows in the middle of the afternoon. Her Mom brings her a sandwich. A glass of water. And then a whole host of prescription meds. Hazel eyes them with indifference.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... it's a side effect of dying. - A STARBUCKS. Hazel sits alone reading a dog-eared, heavily underlined copy of a novel ("An Imperial Affliction" by Peter Van Houten). She only looks up when distracted by a squeal of delight. A YOUNG GUY has lifted a YOUNG GIRL over his shoulder playfully. He spins her around. Hazel watches a beat - goes back to the book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which is what was happening to me. And we CUT BACK TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - SAME Frannie continues to talk to the doctor. Hazel continues to dangle her feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... some days she won't even get out of bed. The Doctor scratches his beard, thinking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I may switch you to Zoloft. Or Lexapro. And twice a day instead of once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why stop there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hmm?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keep `em coming. I can take it. I'm like the Keith Richards of cancer kids. The Doctor looks at Frannie who just shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you been going to that Support Group I suggested? Instead of answering, Hazel looks at her Mom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's gone a few times.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not sure it's for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you're depressed -- HAZEL (EXASPERATED) I'm not de--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- support Groups are a great way to connect with people who are...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the same journey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Journey?" Really?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just give it a chance, ok? For me. Hazel rolls her eyes, knows she's lost this battle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who knows? You might even find it... enlightening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - DAY CLOSE UP on PATRICK (30s, pony-tail). He has a guitar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... we are gathered here today - literally - in the heart of Jesus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Hazel who just shakes her head. This is the lamest thing she could be doing right now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who would like to share their story with the group? The basement is filled with SICK PEOPLE. Hazel among them. Most are under the age of 18. QUICK CUTS:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jillian. 15. Lymphoma.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Angel. 17. Ewing sarcoma.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Patrick. 34. Testicular. It started a few years ago, when I was... As Hazel watches, bored, and Patrick continues, we hear:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) I'll spare you the gory details of Patrick's ball cancer. Basically, they found it in his nuts, cut most of it out, he almost died, but he didn't die, and now here he is - divorced, friendless, addicted to video games, exploiting his cancertastic past in the heart of Jesus - "literally" - to show us that one day - if we're lucky - we could be just like him. They all say:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "We're here for you Patrick." Hazel says it the least enthusiastically. She locks eyes with her only friend in Support Group, a blonde kid with an eye patch, ISAAC. He's also shaking his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who else would like to share? (NO RESPONSE) Hazel? Oh no. Patrick gestures for her to speak. Reluctantly she stands, sighs...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm, uh, Hazel. 16. (BEAT) Thyroid originally but with quite the impressive satellite colony in my lungs. Not much more to say, Hazel is about to sit down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And how are you doing Hazel? Hazel has no idea how to answer that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) You mean besides the terminal cancer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . But that's not what she says. She says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright? I guess...? Isaac tries not to laugh at this. Hazel sits back down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "We're here for you Hazel." Hazel exhales. This is not at all helpful. A few more beats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe now I'll play a song...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frannie sits in the car in the parking lot, reading from a book, waiting for Group to be over. She sees the church door open and puts the book away. Hazel comes out. Frannie looks at her like "well, was it great?" Hazel just exhales and gets in the car. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - ANOTHER DAY "America's Next Top Model" is on the TV. Hazel sits on one side of the L-shaped couch, flipping through her novel. Frannie and Hazel's dad MICHAEL (40s, kind, doing his best to stay positive) sit on the other side, watching her - but trying not to make it seem that way. After a few beats:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Friday night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hmm?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was just thinking... you should call your friends, see what they're up to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's ok. Frannie and Michael look at one another, don't say anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wanna see a movie? Hazel looks up from the book. Sees her parents. Gets an idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you guys go to a movie? (off their look) (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You haven't been out in a while. Go. Have fun. Take the night off. Frannie and Michael look at one another again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a really good show. Hazel sighs. And just like that, everyone goes back to what they were doing. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: which plays over:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) And that was my life. - Hazel watching TV, book in hand. - Hazel in another doctor's office. - Hazel popping pills.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Reality shows. Doctor's appointments. Eight prescription drugs, three times a day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel and her parents in the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) And worse worse worst of all... support group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ugh. You can't make me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course we can, we're your parents. Hazel frowns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel, you need to get out of the house. Make friends. Be a teenager.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you want me to be a teenager, don't send me to Support Group. Buy me a fake ID so I can go to clubs and drink gimlets and take pot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't take pot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See, that's the kind of thing I would know with a fake ID.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get in the car. Hazel mock stabs herself in the stomach with an invisible sword. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - ESTABLISHING A small Episcopalian sanctuary in suburban Indianapolis.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) And so I went... Frannie's car pulls up close to the back entrance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Not because I wanted to or because I thought it would help. But for the same reason I did anything these days... Hazel, oxygen tank in toe, gets out of the car with Frannie's assistance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) ... to make my parents happy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you gonna sit here and wait the whole time?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course not, no. I... (she totally is) I have errands to run. Hazel knows she's not planning to run any errands. She doesn't press the issue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ok.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Love you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Love you too Mom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) The only thing worse than biting it from cancer - is having a kid bite it from cancer. As Frannie gets back in the car, she shouts to her daughter:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Make some friends! Hazel just shakes her head. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - SAME Hazel walks towards the elevator. An EXTREMELY SICK LOOKING KID holds it open for her. Hazel thinks better of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll take the stairs. The KID nods. The doors shut. Hazel is reminded - it could always be worse. She turns to go, walking right into:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ooph. Sorry!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (we will come to know him as GUS). Tall, lean, muscular, straight short mahogany hair, blue eyes. Hazel has never seen a better looking kid in her life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My bad. No, it's... For a brief moment, the Earth stops. They stand looking at one another. Hazel is speechless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me. With the Beautiful Boy watching, a wan smile on his face, Hazel shuffles off as fast as she can, ducking into:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - SAME Hazel catches her breath. Shakes her head. Surprised at herself. She looks in the mirror. So doesn't like what she sees. The Earth starts moving again. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel sits in the Circle of Sick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who would like to begin? No volunteers. Hazel catches sight of the Beautiful Boy, sitting next to Isaac. He seems to be watching her, that same flirty smile on his face. She self-consciously looks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isaac, I know you're facing a challenging time. Perhaps you would like to say something... Isaac nods, rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, um... I'm Isaac. 17. Eye cancer. (BEAT) It's looking like another surgery in a couple weeks. After which, well, I'll be blind... Hazel tries to focus on what Isaac's saying but it's difficult. She still feels the Beautiful Boy's gaze on her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not that I'm complaining or anything. I know a lot of you have it way worse but, still, I mean, you know, being blind's gonna suck... As Isaac shares, the Beautiful Boy doesn't look away from Hazel. Hazel finds this intimidating. And intimidation irritates her. So she decides to play the game with him, meeting his gaze and holding it just as firmly. A staring contest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...My girlfriend helps. And friends like Augustus here... Isaac nods towards the Beautiful Boy who now has a name -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He still doesn't look away from Hazel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So... yeah. That's what's up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "We're here for you Isaac." The staring contest continues another few beats until:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And does your friend want to speak? This causes the Beautiful Boy to momentarily look away. Aha, he's lost the contest! Hazel smiles, flicks her eyebrows up as if to say "Victory is mine!" He smiles back at her, the most radiant smile on the planet. He turns back to the Group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi. I'm Augustus Waters. 17. Had a touch of osteosarcoma bout a year and a half ago - lost this baby as a result...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Gus holds up his right leg - a prosthetic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But really I'm just here at Isaac's request.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And how are you feeling Augustus?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me? Oh I'm grand. I'm on a roller coaster that only goes up, my friend. Hazel smiles. Gus catches this. Embarrassed, she stops smiling and looks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps you'd like to share your fears with the group, Augustus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My fears? Gus thinks about this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oblivion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oblivion?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON Hazel, intrigued.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, see... I intend to live an extraordinary life. To be remembered. If I'm scared of anything it's... not doing that. Patrick doesn't quite have the tools to deal with that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would, uh, anyone like to speak to that? And Hazel's hand goes up. Even Patrick is surprised by that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel! That's unexpected. Hazel stands, takes a second to gather her thoughts. Augustus watches her, waits for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just wanna say... there will come a time when, you know, all of us are dead. Gus is now even more fixed on her than before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It might be tomorrow. Might be a million years from now but... it's gonna happen. And when it does, enough generations will come and go, there'll be no one left to remember Cleopatra. Or Mozart. Or Muhammad Ali, let alone any of us, right? The look on Gus's face is unreadable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oblivion's inevitable. And if that scares you, well, I suggest you ignore it. God knows it's what everyone else does. A beat. And then an enormous smile spreads across Gus's face, not a flirty smile but a surprised one, a real one. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel waits for her Mom's car to appear. Across the parking lot, she sees Isaac going at it with a redhead, MONICA (17), sucking face like there's no tomorrow against the door of her green Pontiac Firebird. Between kisses, we can hear:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Always. Always. And Hazel hears:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Literally. Hazel turns to find the Beautiful Boy, Augustus, standing right next to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought we were in a church basement but apparently we were literally in the heart of Jesus. Hazel smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Someone should probably tell him, don't you think? Jesus? Seems kinda dangerous keeping all these kids with cancer in your heart. Gus laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's your name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No your full name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel Grace Lancaster. Gus nods to himself, smiles. Still fixated on her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't say anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you looking at me like that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because you're beautiful. Hazel is taken aback. No one's ever said that to her before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I enjoy looking at beautiful people and I decided a while back not to deny myself the simpler pleasures of existence. Particularly given that, as you so astutely pointed out, we're all gonna die pretty soon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not beaut -- A CUTE YOUNG GIRL walks past them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey Gus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey Alisa. Hazel isn't surprised that other girls know Gus. Of course they do. She turns back towards Isaac and Monica pawing at each other. She hears:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Always. Always.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's with the "always?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Always" is their thing. They'll "always" love each other and whatnot. Must have texted "always" to each other at least four million times this year. They continue to watch the show. It's pretty gross. Isaac squeezes Monica's breast like a clown horn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's gotta be hurting her boob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's watch a movie. Hazel is again surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. Um. Uh... (yes!) Sure. Yeah. I'm... pretty free this
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No I mean now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hmm?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean "now?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got a car. He shrugs. Hazel has never seen someone so confident.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You could be an axe murderer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is that possibility. (BEAT) Come on Hazel Grace... take a risk. As Hazel mulls this over, Gus reaches into his pocket and pulls out, of all things, a pack of cigarettes! Hazel is in disbelief. He flips the box open, puts a cigarette between his lips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my god. Oh. My. God. You're kidding right? (off his look) You just ruined the whole thing!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whole thing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What, you think that's cool? Oh you idiot! There's always a hamartia, isn't there? And yours is - even though you had FREAKING CANCER you give money to a corporation for the chance to acquire EVEN MORE CANCER!? Ugh. And you were doing so well. As she rants, Gus continues to look at her with that smile on his face. Hazel does not find it so amusing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me tell you... not being able to breathe? Sucks. Totally sucks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hamartia? Hazel folds her arms and turns away from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A fatal flaw. Gus takes a beat and then moves to face her, the smile still etched on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They don't hurt you unless you light them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've never lit one. Hazel turns back to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a metaphor. See? You put the thing that kills you between your teeth. But you don't give it the power to do the killing. Hazel is floored. And impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Metaphor. Gus holds her gaze. And it's at this point Frannie pulls up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi sweetheart. Ready for some "Model?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Hazel looks at Gus, cigarette dangling from his lips. Cool as anything. Handsome as hell. She looks back at her mom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't tonight. (off her confused look) I've made plans with Augustus Waters. And with that, she walks off. Frannie looks at the boy with the cigarette in his mouth. This could be trouble. Or awesome. Or both. And we CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel is terrified. Turns out, Gus is the world's worst driver. When he brakes, her body flies forward against the seatbelt. And when he hits the gas, seconds later, her neck snaps back in the seat. Gus sees the look on her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I failed the test a couple times.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Most amputees can drive with no problem but... yeah. Not me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm surprised you have a license.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me about it! Another brake forces Hazel against the seat belt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The fourth time I took the test... it was going about how this is going... and when it was over, the instructor looks at me and goes, "your driving, while unpleasant... is not technically unsafe."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aha. Cancer perk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Total cancer perk. A few beats of silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what happened to you? Hazel takes a deep breath. She's told this story before but somehow this seems different.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was 13 when they found it. And as she speaks, we see it unfold. SMASH CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FLASHBACK 13-YEAR OLD HAZEL has a biopsy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Stage IV thyroid cancer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FLASHBACK 13-YEAR OLD HAZEL on the operating table. It's a nightmare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) I had surgery first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FLASHBACK This poor little girl is taking a beating. And it's just getting started. - Radiation treatment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Then Radiation... - Having her head shaved by Frannie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Then Chemo... - With a PICC line in a chemo chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) All of which worked for a while. - A RADIOLOGIST looks at an X-ray. He's not pleased.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) And then stopped working. - 14-Year Old Hazel lies in bed, struggling to breathe. Frannie runs her fingers through her hair. Dad calls 9-1-1.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) And then my lungs started filling up with water. - In the ICU, her parents standing over her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) That should have been the end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (through the tears) Are you ready, sweetie? 14-Year Old Hazel nods. Michael can't keep it together any longer. He completely breaks down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) But it wasn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sun shines in the room. 14-year old Hazel eats ice chips, the color has returned to her cheeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) The antibiotics kicked in. They drained the fluid from my lungs. And in time I got better. Stronger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slightly older Hazel is getting more intravenous medication. It's never ending.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) I even found myself in an experimental trial. You know the ones that are famous in the Republic of Cancervania for not working. - A SECOND RADIOLOGIST examines a second X-ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) It's called Phalanxifor. Didn't work in over 70 percent of patients but, for some reason... The Radiologist looks surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) ...it worked in me. They called it "The Miracle." And finally, BACK TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - SAME Gus has one eye on the road, the other on Hazel. He was impressed with her before. He's totally dazzled now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tumors shrank, my mets have hardly grown since... (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course my lungs still suck but, theoretically, they could continue to suck in just this way for, I dunno, a while maybe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So are you back in school or...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Got my GED.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A college girl! Well that explains the aura of sophistication... He smiles at her. She smiles back. Shoves his upper arm playfully. They're easing into each other. Eventually Gus's car pulls into his driveway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're here. He's as good at parking as he is at driving. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - SAME Hazel follows Gus inside. She quickly notices all sorts of engraved plaques and framed signs with phrases like "Home is Where the Heart Is" and "True Love is Born from Hard Times." Hazel looks at Gus quizzically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My parents call them "encouragements." (rolling his eyes) Don't ask. Gus's MOM and DAD (40s) are in the kitchen making dinner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey guys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (taps his leg) Didn't cut this fella off for the hell of it. Though it is an excellent weight-loss strategy. Legs are heavy!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's your health now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: for fourteen months.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's fantastic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm very lucky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON Hazel, checking herself out in the mirror. Seems to like what she sees a lot more than before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gus and Michael, downstairs:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Son, you have to understand... Hazel's still pretty sick. She will be the rest of her life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Hazel, who can hear all of this. She stops what she's doing and listens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She'll want to keep up with you - she's that kind of girl - but the truth is, her lungs -- HAZEL You ready Gus? Hazel appears, silencing her Father mid-sentence. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Behind the Indianapolis Museum of Art is 152 Acres of Gardens and Grounds. Hazel and Gus walk together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this where you bring all your romantic conquests?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every last one. (BEAT) Probably why I'm still a virgin. Hazel laughs, elbows him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not a virgin. (off his look) Are you really? Gus picks a STICK up from the dirt. Draws a BIG CIRCLE in it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See this? This circle is virgins... Now Gus draws a much smaller circle inside that circle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And this... is 17 year old dudes with one leg. Hazel laughs. Point made. He grabs her hand, helps her walk up a tiny hill. Once up there, Gus lays a blanket on the ground. They sit, looking out over a rather odd SCULPTURE - a set of GIANT WHITE BONES where children can jump and play.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Funky Bones" by Joep Van Lieshout.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sounds Dutch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he is. Much like Rik Smits. And tulips. Hazel raises an eyebrow at Gus. He's sure taking this Amsterdam/Dutch thing pretty far. He removes some sandwiches and orange juice out of a basket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sandwich?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me guess -- GUS (NODS) Dutch cheese. And tomato. (she takes one) The tomatoes are Mexican. Sorry. They eat for a second, their eyes watching the children play on the bones.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How cool is that? A skeleton being used as a playground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You do love your symbols.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Speaking of which... Gus stands up, takes a cigarette, puts it in his mouth. He clears his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're probably wondering why you're sitting here eating a bad cheese sandwich and drinking orange juice with a guy in a Rik Smits jersey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It has crossed my mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel Grace, like so many before you - and I say this with great affection - you spent your Wish... moronically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was thir--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hush! I'm in the midst of a grand soliloquy here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry. Please, continue...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were young. Impressionable. The Grim Reaper staring you in the face. And the fear of dying with your one true Wish left ungranted led you to rush into making one you didn't really want, for how could little Hazel Grace, having never read "An Imperial Affliction" ever know that her one TRUE wish was to visit Mr. Peter Van Houten in his Amsterdamian exile. Hazel nods in agreement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you were smart, you would have saved your wish til the time in your life when you really knew your true self.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Gus stops talking. Hazel is confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I... didn't save it. Gus smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good thing I saved mine. Hazel cocks her head to one side. What is he talking about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Got it in exchange for the leg. (BEAT) And I still have it. She starts to realize.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you saying -- GUS I'm not gonna give you my Wish or anything. But I too have an interest in meeting Peter Van Houten and it wouldn't make much sense to meet him without the girl who introduced me to his book, now would it? (Hazel's eyes widen) I talked to the Genies and they're in total agreement. (BEAT) We leave on May third. Hazel is so excited that she grabs Gus and pulls him into a hug. Their faces close, lips inches apart, and just when it looks like something might happen -- HAZEL Wait a minute. (BEAT) Are you only doing this so I'll kiss you? A beat. Gus blinks a few times.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cause I'd totally kiss you either way. And kiss him she does. He's surprised. And when it's over, they sit back, look at one another. A magic moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seriously... why are you doing this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because Hazel Grace... I found my Wish. And Hazel is beyond touched. We hear:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you out of your mind?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frannie folds laundry while Hazel pleads her case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's too much, Haze. We can't accept something like that from a virtual stranger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's not a stranger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be gross.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's still "no," I'm afraid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can we at least ask Dr. Maria?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where Hazel's oncologist DR. MARIA shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARIA That's out of the question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You said the PET scan was encouraging!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARIA The PET scan is encouraging. We just don't know how long it'll stay that way. What if you get sick in a foreign country?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They have doctors in Amsterdam. And cancer. Someone will know what to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARIA Be that as it may, without someone familiar with your particular case, I can't -- HAZEL (turns to her Mom) So you'll come too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Genies can hook it up. They're loaded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've never been to Amsterdam, have you Mom? And judging from her face, seems she'd kinda like to. Dr. Maria looks at Frannie, shrugs - kid's got a point. Hazel smiles. And on that smile, we SMASH CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Over which, we HEAR:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) And then this happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: [Note: There's no sound in this sequence. Just images.] Hazel wakes up screaming in the middle of the night, shaking and holding her head. Frannie and Michael burst in. Mom grabs her crying daughter, frightened beyond belief, waves to Michael to call for help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) People talk about the courage of cancer patients. And I do not deny that courage... He leaves the room to do so and Fran stays behind, rocking with her daughter, promising her it'll all be ok. Whatever nightmare this is, it's going to end. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still silent. Michael drives, trying to keep it together. Frannie's in the back with Hazel's head in her lap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Hazel continues to scream in silence, whether from pain or terror, we do not know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) I'd been poked and stabbed and poisoned for years and still I trod on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael carries Hazel into the chaotic emergency room. They're practically running. There's still no sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) But make no mistake... The doctors rally to assist the screaming, crying child. She's wheeled away from her family who can only watch. We stay with her and WE HEAR:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) In that moment I would have been very, very happy to die.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - ICU - MORNING The sound returns. And it's the sound of a heart monitor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEEP. BEEP. It's also the sound of a working heart. Hazel has made it through. Her eyes open. A NURSE is there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're ok, Hazel. Even Hazel seems surprised by that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you like to see your parents? Hazel nods. The Nurse goes to get them. Soon they come bounding in, crying and kissing her repeatedly. So much relief. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Hazel's bed has been raised up so she can talk to her parents "comfortably."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They thought it was a brain tumor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It wasn't - thank god -- 46.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The usual. Fluid in the lungs, preventing oxygenation. They put that in... There's a TUBE in Hazel's side draining fluid into a plastic bladder that hangs off her bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drained a liter and a half last night. (That's a lot of fluid.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The good news is... no tumor growth. No new tumors in your body. Hazel nods. That is a relief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're all so relieved. Frannie embraces her daughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is just a thing Hazel. It's a thing we can live with. Hazel nods again. Only in the universe of Hazel Grace Lancaster is something like this just a thing. Meanwhile:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - WAITING AREA - LATER Here's Gus, his foot tapping nervously on the floor. It's unclear how long he's been waiting there. He sees Michael walk down the hall. Races after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Lancaster! How's she doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Better, thank you. Much better. Gus nods, as relieved as the rest of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They won't let me in. Family only.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry -- GUS No I get it. Will you just... will you tell her I was here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course I will. Gus smiles. And sits back down. Though he won't get to see her, he still wants to stay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gus. Michael really likes this kid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you go home, get some rest? Gus looks up. That might be for the best. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - CONFERENCE ROOM - DAYS LATER Hazel and her Parents sit at a very large conference table along with Dr. Maria and THREE OTHER ONCOLOGISTS - her whole "Cancer Team."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The great news is... Phalanxifor continues to control your tumor growth. (BEAT) The not so great news is we're still seeing serious problems with fluid accumulation. (BEAT) So how should we proceed? Silence. Hazel looks around the room, waits for someone to answer. No one does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Um, I feel like I'm not the most qualified person to answer that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was talking to Dr. Simmons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SIMMONS (late 60s, white beard, old school) speaks next.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SIMMONS It's a strange case. Normally the tumors start resisting the treatment. But that hasn't happened here - yet. Hazel hears the "yet" the loudest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SIMMONS Unfortunately, the drug may be worsening the edema.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARIA But if we stopped it entirely, we're likely to face even graver dangers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So we're gonna do nothing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARIA That's what we have to decide. The truth is... very few people have been on Phalanxifor as long as Hazel has. We don't really know the long term effects. That comforts no one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't I just get like a lung transplant or something? The Doctors look at one another like "who wants to take that one?" Eventually:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARIA You would not be considered a... strong candidate for a transplant. Hazel takes that in, nods, tries to pretend it didn't bother her. Sensitive Michael on the other hand starts to cry a little bit. He grabs Frannie's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SIMMONS We're trying to prevent endothelial growth while at the same time preventing immunosorbent... As Dr. Simmons drones on with some cancer gobbledygook, Hazel's eyes remain firmly fixed on her parents. She hates what she's doing to them. And seeing them holding hands, crying but trying not to cry - it jogs a memory. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FLASHBACK We saw this once before. It looks like the end for 13-year old Hazel. Her father is weeping off to the side while her mom stands over her, holding her hand, and asking:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (through the tears) Are you ready, sweetie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: year old Hazel nods. The doctors get to work. The anaesthetic takes hold and Hazel goes under. But not enough. Cause she totally hears her mother say:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I won't be a mom anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She falls into her husband's chest. And we're BACK TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - CONFERENCE ROOM Hazel comes out of the memory when her parents see her staring at them. She tries to shake it off. Dr. Simmons is still talking nonsense when:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have a question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARIA Yes Hazel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I still go to Amsterdam? Dr. Simmons can't help himself. He laughs. Everyone looks at him. He clears his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SIMMONS That would not be wise at this juncture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SIMMONS Excuse me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not, Dr. Simmons?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SIMMONS I -- The doctors are trying to be delicate here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARIA It would... increase some risks -- HAZEL So does going to the mall -- DR. MARIA Yes but an airplane?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They have oxygen on airplanes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's my life, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SIMMONS You're Stage IV -- 50.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have this opportunity I may never have again. If the medicine's working, I don't see why -- DR. SIMMONS Because, Hazel. (BEAT) Look, I don't know any other way to say this... You're just too sick. And this is like a punch in the gut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SIMMONS I'm sorry. Everyone feels horrible now. Dr. Maria, Frannie and Michael, and even Hazel. This meeting couldn't have gone worse. And we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - DRIVEWAY Hazel parent's bring her home from the hospital. She looks miserable. It's clear the last few days have been a big emotional set back. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her parents tuck her in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll be right outside. Hazel nods. Her phone buzzes. She looks at it. A text from Gus that reads: "ok?" Hazel looks at it. And she doesn't write back. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel sits staring at nothing. The house phone rings. Michael comes in from another room with the phone in hand. Whispers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gus again. Hazel thinks about it - silently shakes her head, no. Michael says into the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry Gus, she's asleep. Hazel stands and goes into her bedroom, clearly depressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel reads from "An Imperial Affliction." Her phone buzzes again. "Augustus." It just says "hello?" Again she ignores it. And then a second text. She looks at it. "The silence is deafening." She puts the phone back down. Hazel's heart breaks. She can't take it anymore. She picks the phone back up. She texts the following:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: don't know if you'll understand this but I can't see you anymore. I mean I want to. I just..." She thinks about the rest. She writes: "I'm a grenade." She sends the text. Waits. And then there's more to say. She sends a second text. "When I look at you, all I can see is what I'm going to put you through. I can't have that. I'm sorry." She sends that text. Waits. He writes back. "Ok." Hazel reads it. Writes back: "Ok." A beat. Gus responds: "oh my god, stop flirting with me!" Hazel smiles - she can't help herself! - but she must. She gets her emotions in check. Puts the phone away. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - ESTABLISHING An ugly day in Indianapolis.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - SAME Inside, Hazel is about as miserable as the weather. The sky - and the circumstances - have cast a grey pall over the day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - BACKYARD Hazel walks out back. Looks up at the clouds, threatening rain but not yet delivering it. She sits down in the grass, on the verge of tears. She looks at the old rusty SWING SET that's been in her backyard for years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . And starts to cry. Just for a few brief moments, she lets herself cry. Then she wipes the tears. Becomes strong again. And makes a decision. Hazel dials her phone. We hear:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Hazel Grace!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi Augustus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Are you crying, Hazel Grace?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kind of.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) What's the matter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. I want to go to Amsterdam. And I want him to tell us what happens after the book and I don't want my particular life and also the sky is making me sad and there's this old swing set that my Dad made for me when I was a kid. It's just... everything. Hazel is on the verge of losing it again. A few beats of silence pass by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) I demand to see this swing set of tears. Hazel can't help but smile and we CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Same backyard - only now Hazel is with Gus. Which makes everything better. They both look at the swing set.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see your point. (BEAT) That is one sad swing set. Hazel nudges her head onto his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks for coming over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You do realize... trying to keep your distance from me will in no way lessen my affection for you. Hazel says nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All efforts to save me from you will fail. Hazel looks at him. He's sure not making this easy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this about Amsterdam? Cause we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not about Amsterdam. It's about me. It's about...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grenades. Hazel nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I get it. One day you're going to explode in a huge ball of fire and everyone close to you will die in your wake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exactly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's already two people in your life you're going to destroy. Why add a third to that list. Am I right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's why I don't have a hamster. Gus is silent. He can't argue. They stand there quietly a few more beats, looking out at the swing set. Until:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have got to do something about this frigging swing set.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel sits at the computer screen writing a Craigslist post. Gus stands next to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Swing Set Needs Home."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Desperately Lonely Swing Set Needs Loving Home."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Lonely, Vaguely Pedophilic Swing Set Seeks Butts of Children." Gus laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No? Gus laughs harder. Hazel laughs with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's why. Hazel looks at him, not understanding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In case you were wondering... that's why I like you. (beat, off her look) You're so busy being you that you have no idea how utterly unprecedented you are. Hazel absorbs that. Her feelings for this boy in a tangle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - BACKYARD Gus and Hazel watch as a TOWNIE finishes loading the swing set into the back of his PICK-UP. Gus salutes the swing set as the truck drives off. Then he sneaks a quick kiss on Hazel's cheek. She shoots him a look. Gus throws up his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Friendly. She playfully elbows him away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel walks with Isaac out of Support Group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you like him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course I like him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you don't want to hook up with him? Hazel doesn't know what she wants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's complicated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel is at her computer reading a new email from Lidewij Vliegenthart. Clearly Hazel was not expecting this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) "Dear Hazel, I have received word via the Genies that you will be visiting us with Augustus Waters and your mother beginning on the 4th. A week away! Peter and I are delighted and cannot wait to -- Hazel is confused. She stands and walks into the hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom? No response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom! (STILL NOTHING)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: !!! Frannie races out of her room in a towel, dripping wet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it, what's wrong?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry, I... I didn't know you were in the shower.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bath. I was just... just trying to take a bath for five seconds. What's the matter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you ever call the Genies to tell them the trip is off? I just got an email from Peter Van Houton's assistant. She still thinks we're coming. Frannie purses her lips and squints past Hazel. Clearly unsure what to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Frannie can't keep a straight face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not supposed to tell you until your father gets home. (BEAT) We're going to Amsterdam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (still not believing) Really...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Maria called last night and made a convincing case that you need to live -- HAZEL (YELLING) I LOVE YOU SO MUCH!! Hazel can't move all that fast to hug her Mom so Frannie comes to her and they embrace. After:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm getting back in the tub now. When she leaves Hazel grabs her cell phone. ANGLE ON IT. Hazel sends Gus the following text: "STILL FREE MAY 3? :-)" A moment later Gus responds: "EVERYTHING'S COMING UP WATERS!" Hazel is over the moon with excitement. She smiles, then tries to calm herself, knowing it's the best thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispering to her lungs) One week, lungs. Keep your shit together one more week...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luggage waits by the door, including oxygen tanks and medical equipment. Frannie makes breakfast as Hazel enters, now dressed and excited for the trip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amsterdam!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amsterdam! And a moment later Michael joins them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amsterdam! They're all going crazy with excitement! CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael finishes loading up the car. Kisses his wife goodbye. He embraces Hazel. She hugs him back and of course he starts to cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you. I'm so proud of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For what? Michael lets go of her and wipes away his tears. They look at each other. Unable to help himself, he grabs her for another hug. Hazel lets him, laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The car is packed with oxygen tanks, a suitcase for clothes, another for medicines and back-up medicines just in case etc. Frannie pulls up to Gus's house. They get out of the car and head to the front door, buzzing with excitement. As they get close, they can hear a commotion inside. A WOMAN'S VOICE yelling something unclear, followed by:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . IT BELONGS TO ME! Frannie immediately puts her arm around Hazel and quickly spins her back to the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can't eavesdrop, Hazel. Back at the car, far out of earshot, they wait. Hazel unsure what that was about. Frannie politely honks the horn. A moment later Gus emerges from the house, smiling. A travel bag over his shoulder and a cigarette dangling from his lips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Always a pleasure to see you ma'am. (BEAT) Hello, Hazel Grace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ok.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ok. Frannie doesn't know what to make of any of that. She just says, when they stop and look at her:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amsterdam!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - ESTABLISHING A SKYCAP helps Hazel, Gus and Frannie with all their bags and equipment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They wait in line for the security checkpoint. When it's Hazel's turn she unhooks the plastic nubbins from her nose. Gus places the oxygen tank on the conveyer belt. Hazel takes slow, careful steps through the metal detector. She seems determined to get through this without any help. But upon reaching the other side it's clear that even these few steps without oxygen were a struggle. Hazel holds on to the side of the conveyer belt to steady herself. As soon as her tank reappears she puts the cannula back in place. Still light-headed, Hazel closes her eyes and focuses on her breathing. She catches her mom looking at her, nervously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (with some difficulty) Amsterdam!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arriving at the Gate area they draw curious looks from the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Hazel with her oxygen tank, Gus with his noticeable limp and Frannie helping with the equipment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: gets up so that Hazel and Gus can sit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh that's not necessary. But they give up their seats anyway. Hazel and Gus take them. We see various Passengers watching. Hazel ignores the attention until a LITTLE GIRL (6, cute braids) appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's in your nose?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's called a Cannula. These tubes give me oxygen and help me breathe. The GIRL'S MOTHER swoops in, a little frantic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jackie... Oh, I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no. It's alright.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would they help me breathe too?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I dunno. Wanna try? Hazel removes her cannula and let's the Little Girl try it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tickles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think I'm breathing better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... I'd love to give you my cannula but... I kinda really need the help. The Little Girl nods, hands it back to Hazel, who quickly reattaches it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks for letting me try it. They smile at each other before the Little Girl walks back to her family. She waves. Hazel waves back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) We will now begin pre-boarding Flight 144 to Amsterdam. For those passengers in need of extra assistance...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think that's us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel sits in the middle with Frannie on the aisle and Gus at the window. He looks around, antsy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you never been on a plane before? Gus shakes his head, he has not. And he's nervous. He pulls a cigarette out of his pocket and puts it in his mouth. Within seconds a FLIGHT ATTENDANT rushes over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, you can't smoke on this plane. Or... any plane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cigarette in his mouth) I don't smoke. The Flight Attendant shoots him a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a metaphor. He puts the killing thing in his mouth but doesn't give it the power to kill him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That metaphor is prohibited on today's flight. Gus nods and puts the cigarette away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Flight attendants, prepare for departure." The engines roar to life and the plane accelerates towards take off. Gus is getting more worried by the second. He grabs the arm rest, his eyes wide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ok? Gus doesn't say it back. Hazel laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is what it feels like to ride in a car with you. Gus grabs Hazel's hand as the plane lifts off. He looks out the window - they're flying! - and then back to Hazel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're flying! Look! Hazel smiles at his enthusiasm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holy -- look at that?! NOTHING HAS EVER LOOKED LIKE THAT EVER IN ALL OF HUMAN HISTORY! He's adorable at this moment. Hazel can't resist leaning over to give him a kiss on the cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (not looking up from her
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just so you know, I'm right here. Sitting next to you. Your mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're just friends, Mom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is. I'm not. Hazel shoots him a look. Gus shrugs - "what, it's the truth." Hazel just shakes her head. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

result.heading: NOTHING HAS EVER LOOKED LIKE THAT EVER IN ALL OF HUMAN HISTORY

direction.raw_text: . Mid-flight, the plane is dark, Frannie's asleep. Hazel and Gus watch the same gory action movie. Actually, he watches the movie. She just watches him watch it. He watches it with gusto. Hazel continues to watch him. Try as she might, she's falling in love. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : the PLANE touching down. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - TAXI CAB - MORNING Hazel, Gus, and Frannie ride in the back of a YELLOW CAB.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Americans?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're from Indiana.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Indiana. They steal from the Indians but the keep the name, yes? Hazel and Gus share a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Something like that. Meanwhile, the landscape outside is flat and dusty, with dirt tracks and the occasional concrete building. In other words, it looks more like Indianapolis than Holland.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the Driver) This is Amsterdam?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes and no. Amsterdam is like the rings of a tree. It gets older as you get closer to the center. Soon enough, the cab takes an off-ramp and turns a corner and suddenly, it's as if they're transported - not only to another universe but to another time as well. We see MULTI-COLORED ROW HOUSES lined on both sides of a windy CANAL. HOUSEBOATS float against the edges and everyone rides BICYCLES down cobblestone streets. They're astounded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gus helps Hazel and Frannie bring their stuff into the room. We see a WICKER BASKET of gifts - presents from the Genies - welcoming their arrival. Hazel, exhausted, sits on the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be right down the hall. Hazel nods, already drifting off to sleep. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some time later. Hazel stirs. Her Mom is seated in a sagging, paisley CHAIR across from the bed reading a TRAVEL GUIDE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Actually, it's five o'clock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How was the park?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never made it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? I like watching you sleep. Hazel shoots Frannie a look. Even in an exotic city, her Mom still can't enjoy herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I promise I'll do crazy Mom stuff tonight while you and Gus are at dinner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have reservations at a place called Oranjee. Mr. Van Houten set it up. Very fancy according to the Book. And romantic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm just saying...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: year old girl running free with an older boy on the streets of a foreign city famous for its vice and debauchery... is totally cool with you. Is that what you're saying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (beat, excited) Let's get you dressed! Hazel just shakes her head. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frannie opens the door to find Gus in a perfectly tailored
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: cigarette dangling from his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (calling to the bathroom) Hazel! Gus is here. (TO GUS) Looking sharp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you ma'am. A few beats later Hazel emerges from the bathroom. She wears a knee-length, pale blue SUNDRESS. And she looks...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... (BEAT) Am I under-dressed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look gorgeous. Gus offers Hazel his arm. She takes it. They're ready to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - ON THE TRAM - LATER Hazel and Gus ride the crowded tram through the city. ELM TREES line the canals, their pale petals blowing into the wind like a spring snowstorm. An OLD COUPLE stands to give up their seats - this happens all the time. Hazel again tries to protest and again it falls on deaf ears. She and Gus sit. They look out the window onto the city. Excited. The night just beginning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the edge of the canal, near an ancient bridge. Hazel and Gus are shown to a TABLE right next to the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your table, Mr. And Mrs. Waters. Gus pulls out Hazel's chair for her. A WAITER brings them a bottle of CHAMPAGNE as they sit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The champagne is our gift. Hazel and Gus look at each other. Is this a dream? The champagne is poured and Gus raises his glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ok. Hazel raises hers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ok. They clink glasses and sip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wow that's good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know what Dom Perignon said after he invented champagne? (BEAT) `Come quickly,' he said. `I am tasting the stars!' Hazel and Gus smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Welcome to Oranjee. Would you like a menu or will you have the chef's choice? Gus looks at Hazel. She shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The chef's choice sounds lovely. (the Waiter nods) And can we get more of this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have bottled all the stars for you this evening, my young friends. The Waiter leaves. Hazel and Gus look at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for coming to Amsterdam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for letting me hijack your wish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for wearing that dress which is like whoa. Hazel shakes her head, trying not to smile but unable not to. The Waiter brings two more glasses of champagne and a plate:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Belgian white asparagus with a lavender infusion. Hazel takes a bite.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my god.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah? Gus takes a bite.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is just...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are no words. Meanwhile, down on the water a BOAT passes, filled with merry, drinking LOCALS. One of them raises a glass to them and says something in Dutch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We don't speak Dutch!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She says, "the beautiful couple is beautiful!"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Hazel and Gus smile. This night could not be going any better so far. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Hazel and Gus enjoying their second courses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want this dragon carrot risotto to become a person so I can take it to Vegas and marry it. Hazel leans back in her chair, in need of a breather.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like your suit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks. First time wearing it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That isn't the suit you wear to funerals?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh no. That one's not nearly this nice. (off her look) When I first found out I was sick - I mean, they told me I had like an
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: % chance to be cancer-free. Great odds, sure. But that meant a year of torture, the loss of my leg, and still a 15% chance it might fail. (BEAT) So right before the surgery I asked my parents if I could buy a suit, like a really nice suit, just in case I didn't make it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's your death suit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have one of those. Bought it for my 15th birthday. Don't think I'd wear it on a date, though.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are we on a date?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cocks her head) Watch it. Gus winks. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Dessert on the table. As they euphorically eat:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Angels?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Undecided.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Afterlife?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Well... (BEAT) Maybe I wouldn't go so far as to say no. I just... I'd like some evidence. (GUS NODS) What do you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Absolutely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh for sure. I mean, not like a heaven where you ride unicorns, play harps, and live in a mansion made of clouds but, yeah, I believe in something. Hazel is surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Something becomes of us. It has to. Otherwise what's the point?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe there is no point.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I refuse to accept that. (BEAT) I won't accept it. Hazel thinks about it. She appreciates his conviction but is still not sure she agrees. The hand they've been dealt too unfair. Hazel looks out at the water as she says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you're right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm in love with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . That gets her attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm in love with you. And I know that love is just a shout into the void, and that oblivion is inevitable, and that we're all doomed and that there will come a day when all our labor has been returned to dust, and I know the sun will swallow the only earth we'll ever have, and I am in love with you. (shrugs, matter-of-fact) Sorry. At which point, the Waiter reappears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More stars? Hazel is still too speechless to respond, her eyes fixed on Gus. Eventually Gus answers for them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just the check, please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, sir. (BEAT) Your meal has been paid for by Mr. Van Houten. Gus raises his eyebrows at Hazel. This Van Houten guy is something else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel and Gus on a park bench, his arm around her, looking out over the water. Seeds blow from the elm trees and the reflections of the city ripple in the water below them. Hazel leans into his body, just a little. They stay like that, savoring the best night of both of their lives. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - HOTEL - ESTABLISHING A crisp Spring morning in Amsterdam. The buzz in the air outside is equalled by the buzz in:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - SAME Where Hazel excitedly paces through the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I really don't get that shirt. Hazel wears a screen print t-shirt of Magritte's "Ceci N'est Pas Une Pipe." (A painting of a pipe with words below that mean "This is not a pipe.")
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Van Houten will get it. Trust me. There are like fifty Magritte references in "Imperial Affliction."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "This is not a pipe."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exactly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it is a pipe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No it's not. It's a drawing of a pipe. See? (SHE DOESN'T) All representations of a thing are inherently abstract. A drawing of a thing is not the thing itself. Nor is a t-shirt of a drawing of a thing the thing itself. Frannie is still at a loss but she's impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When did you get so grown up? I feel like it was yesterday I was telling 8-year old Hazel why the sky was blue. You thought I was a genius back then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why is the sky blue?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I say so. A knock on the door. Gus pokes his head in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's ready for some answers!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gus and Hazel stand outside Van Houten's white house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so excited I can barely breathe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As opposed to other days...? She playfully hits him. He takes her arm, picks up the oxygen tank, and up they go towards his front door. As they approach, there's a noticeable NOISE coming from inside the house. It's the deep thump of a BASS BEAT. Loud. Like, obnoxiously loud. Hazel grabs the brass ornament and knocks. They wait. There's no response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe he can't hear over the music? Gus tries again, this time with more force. Still nothing. He tries a third time. Finally, the music stops. They wait. Still excited. A moment later the door swings open. It's a MAN IN PAJAMAS (60s), with a huge potbelly, thinning hair, and a week-old beard. All he says is:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?! Gus and Hazel look to one another. Could it be?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Van Houten? At which point, the Pajama Man slams the door in their faces. Hazel and Gus are too stunned to react. Through the closed door, they hear this:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) (SHOUTING)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Are they here, Peter? So it is PETER VAN HOUTEN. Gus and Hazel can't believe it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) There are two -- (BEAT) Who the hell's "they?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) They are Augustus and Hazel, the young fans with whom you've been corresponding. Gus and Hazel smile at hearing their names. Perhaps this will help things take a turn for the better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) The Americans?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) You invited them, remember?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) You know why I left America, Lidewij? To never have to encounter Americans. Get rid of them. Hazel and Gus can't believe it. This is terrible!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) I will not do this Peter. Be nice. At which point, the door opens - opened by the Woman whose voice they'd been hearing - Van Houten's assistant LIDEWIJ (30s, Dutch, pretty in a bookish way). She virtually shoves Van Houten towards a stunned Gus and Hazel. And they are again face-to-face with Van Houten. One beat, two beats. No one knows what to say. Finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which of you is Augustus Waters? Gus raises his hand tentatively. Van Houten sizes them up. Without another word, he turns and walks inside - at least this time, leaving the door ajar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please. I am sorry. Come in. Hazel and Gus share one more awkward glance before Gus takes a step. Hazel follows. They walk: INT VAN HOUTEN'S HOME - SAME Lidewij leads Gus and Hazel into a living room so sterile it's creepy. The walls are empty and white, there's a single couch, a small ottoman, and a single lounge chair. That's it. Van Houten sits in the chair. Off to the side are two large black garbage bags, full and twist-tied.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Trash?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fan mail. 18 years worth. He never opens it. Van Houten kicks his feet up on the ottoman and crosses his slippers. He motions for them to sit on the couch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yours are the first missives to which I've replied and look where that got me. Hazel and Gus take their seats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scotch?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Um, no thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Augustus Waters?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's 11am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just me then, Lidewij. Scotch and soda.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps some breakfast first Peter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She thinks I have a drinking problem.
direction.name: direction
