direction.raw_text: I also think the Earth is round. Nevertheless, Lidewij pours Peter half a glass and hands it to him. He takes a sip, then sits up straight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you like my book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. We - well, Augustus, he made meeting you his Wish so that we could come here and talk to you. Van Houten says nothing. Takes a long pull on his drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you dress like her on purpose?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looks at her shirt) Kinda.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Van Houten says nothing to that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do not have a drinking problem. I have a Churchillian relationship with alcohol: I can crack jokes and govern England and do anything I want to do. Except not drink. He glances over at Lidewij, who dutifully refills his glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Incidentally, thank you for dinner last night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We bought them dinner last night?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was our pleasure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've come a long way so... what is it I can do for you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have some questions -- VAN HOUTEN Uh-huh...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About what happens, you know... after... the end of your book. Specifically to those who Anna leaves behind. Like her Mom, the Dutch Tulip Man, Sisy -- VAN HOUTEN (INTERRUPTING) How familiar are you with Swedish hip-hop? Hazel looks at Gus. Is he kidding?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would say... limited?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But presumably you know Afasi Och Filthy's seminal album "Flacken."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Um...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lidewij! Play `Bomfalleralla' immediately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Lidewij sighs but she does as she's told. A few seconds later, some loud Swedish rap song blasts from the speakers. Hazel and Gus sit through this, totally baffled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (yelling over the music) I'm sorry, sir. We don't speak Swedish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who the hell speaks Swedish? The important thing is not what nonsense the voices are saying, but what the voices are feeling. The song continues another awkward ten seconds or so before Gus has enough. He gets up and turns off the music.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you messing with us?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pardon?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this some kind of performance?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rudolf Otto said that if you had not encountered the numinous then his work was not for you. And I say to you, my friends, if you cannot hear Afasi Och Filthy's bravadic response to fearfulness, then my work is not for you. Hazel is really getting worried at this point. They came all this way for this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So anyway... when the book ends, Anna's mom -- VAN HOUTEN (raising a hand to silence
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let us imagine that you are racing a tortoise. Hazel and Gus fidget in their seats. Lidewij frowns, clearly feeling bad for them. Van Houten continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tortoise has a ten yard head start. In the time it takes you to run ten yards, the tortoise has moved maybe one yard. And so on, forever. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are faster than the tortoise but you can never catch him, you see, you can only decrease his lead. Now certainly you can run past the tortoise as long as you don't contemplate the mechanics involved but the question of how turns out to be so complicated that no one really solved it until Cantor's proof that some infinities are bigger than other infinities. Hazel and Gus have no idea how to respond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I assume that answers your questions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know what's going on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And yet you seemed so intelligent in print, Mr. Waters. (under his breath) Must be all that cancer in your brain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peter! Gus could throw a punch right now. Hazel tries to calm the situation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can we please, maybe, talk about Anna for a sec? I mean, I understand that the story ends mid- sentence because she dies or she becomes too sick to continue -- VAN HOUTEN I'm not interested in talking about that book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - but that doesn't mean her family and everyone she loves doesn't have a future, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said I'm not interested -- HAZEL (GETTING UPSET) But you promised! (CALMS HERSELF) (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Van Houten, you said you would tell us what happens and that's why we're here. We... I need you tell me. Surely you've thought about it. I mean, as characters -- VAN HOUTEN Nothing happens to them! They're fictions. They cease to exist the moment the novel is over. This is not what Hazel came all this way to hear. She won't accept it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They can't! (again, has to calm
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean, I understand. In a literary sense. But it's impossible NOT to imagine some future -- VAN HOUTEN I can't do this. Lidewij, get rid of them, please. (Lidewij doesn't move, he turns back to Hazel) I won't indulge your childish whims. I refuse to pity you in the manner in which you're accustomed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want your pity -- VAN HOUTEN Of course you do. Like all sick kids, your existence depends on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peter!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (on a roll) You are fated to live out your days as the child you were when diagnosed, the child who believes there is life after a novel ends. And we, as adults, we pity this, so we pay for your treatments, for your oxygen machines. We give you food and water though you are unlikely to live long enough -- LIDEWIJ PETER!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are a side effect of an evolutionary process that cares little for individual lives. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are a failed experiment in mutation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! Lidewij has tears in her eyes. Gus has balled his fists. But not Hazel. Van Houten's words have not phased her one bit. She rises from the couch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey listen douchepants. You're not gonna tell me anything I don't already know about illness. I need one thing and one thing only from you before I walk out of your life and that's for you to tell me what happens to your goddman characters!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I cannot tell you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bullshit!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I cannot -- Van Houten goes to take a drink but...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Make something up. ... Hazel smacks it right the fuck out of his hands, surprising everyone. After a beat:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lidewij. I'll have a martini please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have resigned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh don't be ridiculous. No one moves. Van Houten realizes he's alone in this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like you to leave now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're really not gonna tell us?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would like you... to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Hazel is furious. Gus stands next to her, touches her arm is if to say "come on, enough of this guy." CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - SAME Gus and Hazel come out of the house, practically shaking. As they get to the street, Van Houten has one more thing to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you ever stopped to ask why you care so much about your silly questions? A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go fuck yourself. Van Houten doesn't have a response to that. He just shuts the door. And when he does, that's when Hazel gets emotional.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey. It's ok. It's ok... (beat, an idea) I'll write you a sequel. (she cries harder) I will. Better than any shit that drunk could write. With blood and guts and sacrifice. You'll love it. Hazel nods, then wipes away tears. She fakes a smile and Gus gives her a hug. Afterwards:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I spent your Wish on that asshole.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You did not spend it on him. You spent it on us. They embrace once more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know... I know. Apparently the world is not a wish-granting factory. This gets a real smile from Hazel. That's when Lidewij comes outside. Clearly she's been crying too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so sorry. Circumstance has made him cruel. I thought meeting you would help him, if he would see that his work has shaped real lives, but... I'm very sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Hazel says nothing. Gus holds her in a very protective way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps we can do some sightseeing. Have you seen the Anne Frank House?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not going anywhere with that monster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is not invited.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lidewij walks back from the ticket kiosk with more bad news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid there's no elevator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, um, that's alright.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, there are many stairs. Steep stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can do it! Hazel is not going to stand for any more disappointments today. They are going inside. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - GROUND FLOOR - MOMENTS LATER A VIDEO plays on a MONITOR showing the Nazi invasion of Holland. Hazel and Gus stand with Lidewij in a pack of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and TRAVELERS about to take the tour. Many of them begin to walk up the first flight of stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shall we? Hazel nods. Both Hazel and Gus walk slowly up the stairs. So far so good. They find themselves in an office space.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the bookcase that hid the Frank family and four others. The BOOKCASE is half open. Behind it is an even steeper set of stairs, only wide enough for one person at a time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Some of the Travelers begin to walk up the stairs. Gus looks at Hazel - are you sure we should continue? She begins the climb, determined. Lidewij trails behind, carrying her oxygen tank. Hazel moves very slowly. We are aware of her labored breathing the entire time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: watching and quietly commenting. Just like at the airport, except now in foreign languages. Hazel arrives on the NEXT FLOOR - an empty room. She's definitely starting to struggle. She leans against the wall to catch her breath. Gus comes to her side, wipes her brow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a champion. Hazel smiles. When she's feeling up to it they walk into the next room, also empty. And another staircase, even more narrow and steep - practically a ladder. When Gus sees this he looks at Hazel:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's enough -- HAZEL (RESOLUTE) I'm ok. Hazel very slowly begins the climb. Again we're aware of her every breath. It's dark. And it's becoming very difficult. Near the top Hazel stumbles but is finally able to pull herself through. Once there, she falls to the floor, slumping against the wall, trying to catch her breath. Gus crouches next to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're at the top. That's it. Hazel becomes aware that TOURISTS look at her with concern. She smiles, stands up, nothing to see here. And now they're in the final room - a long, narrow hallway. This is where Anne Frank and 7 other people lived in hiding for as long as they could. There's a TIME LINE detailing their story.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The only member of the whole family to survive was Otto, Anne's father. Gus takes Hazel's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know how you go on, without your family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Lidewij stays behind to study part of the exhibit. Gus leads Hazel into the room at the end of the hallway where a VIDEO details the last days of Anne Frank's life. Over it, we hear a YOUNG GIRL's VOICE reading from the diary. The Travelers stand to watch and listen. Gus and Hazel do the same. The room is dark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) "At such moment's, I don't think about the misery..." Gus and Hazel stand very closely together. The video is the cherry on top of a very emotional day. Hazel watches it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...but about the beauty that still remains." Gus, meanwhile, is just watching Hazel, the same way she watched him on the airplane. After a beat, she catches him. Their eyes meet. The emotions build...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) "Try to recapture the happiness within yourself. Think of all the beauty in everything around you... and be happy." And Hazel KISSES Gus. A most passionate, intense, you-and-me- against-the-world kind of kiss, better than any they've experienced or could even imagine. It seems to last for a small eternity. Eventually, they break away and open their eyes. They quickly notice all the Travelers staring at them. For a brief second, they wonder if that was a very inappropriate thing to do... When suddenly everyone starts clapping for them, moved by the whole thing. One EUROPEAN even shouts "bravo!" Hazel blushes, Gus smiles, bows, he grabs her hand. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They fall onto Gus's bed, kissing. Hazel is very in the moment and now it's Gus who seems nervous. As they kiss:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's above my knee. She ignores him, more kissing. She takes off his shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It tapers a little and then it's just skin -- HAZEL What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Hazel pulls away from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My leg. (BEAT) Just so you're prepared -- HAZEL Oh get over yourself. Hazel kisses him again. Now he tries to pull her shirt off but it gets tangled in with her oxygen tube. He can't figure it out. Eventually the whole thing is hilarious to them. They shake their heads - laughing - certainly not your typical Hollywood movie moment. And yet, for them:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you, Augustus Waters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you too, Hazel Grace. They resume kissing. And we CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gus wakes up in the bed. He looks around for Hazel but she isn't there. On the bed is a piece of paper. A note. It reads: "Dearest Augustus..." Beneath that is a BIG CIRCLE, labeled "Virgins." And in that circle is a SMALLER SECOND CIRCLE labeled "17 year old dudes with one leg." We'll notice part of that circle is now outside the bigger circle. Gus flashes that signature smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel and Gus sit with Frannie drinking coffee in the sun at an outdoor cafe. They're re-enacting yesterday's events.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Get up you fat bastard."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: can't stand up, I'm too drunk."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said "get up."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Standing is for fools!"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God, what an asshole. They both giggle at the whole thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was awful, Mom. You can't imagine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then what happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then we went to the Anne Frank museum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And after that? A quick glance between Hazel and Gus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We just... walked around. Hazel and Gus smile, thoroughly in love but trying to keep it in check in front of her Mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sounds lovely. A few beats later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen... I'm gonna stretch my legs a little. Give the two of you some time to talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Um... ok... As she stands up to leave, Hazel thinks she catches Gus and Frannie making eye contact for a brief second. Once Frannie has left them:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was weird. Gus doesn't respond except to say:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shall we?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They start to walk. Gus takes a cigarette out of his pack, sticks it between his lips. Hazel notices he's struggling with something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Augustus?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's something I have to tell you... They walk in silence a few beats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just before you went into the hospital... There was this... I felt this... ache in my hip. Hazel grabs onto his arm, a lump already forming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh no... Gus takes the cigarette out of his mouth, clenches his teeth tightly, trying not to cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had a PET scan. Gus sits down on a BENCH. Looks up at her. Tries to smile. Before he even says it, she knows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It lit up like a Christmas tree, Hazel...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh god.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The lining of my chest, my liver... everywhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my god no! Hazel loses it in that moment, falling on top of him, hugging him for dear life, her head in his lap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so sorry, Augustus. I'm so so
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry too -- HAZEL It's so unfair -- GUS I should have told you -- HAZEL It's so fucking unfair! A beat. Gus still trying not to cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Apparently the world is... not a wish-granting factory. And at that point, Gus lets it go, lets himself cry and be sad and feel awful. But just for a second. Then he shakes it off, pulls Hazel's face up to his, tries again to smile through the tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you worry about me, Hazel Grace. I'll find a way to hang around and annoy you for a long time. She hugs him, perhaps a little too tightly. He winces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does it hurt?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's ok. (BEAT) I'm ok.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ok.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ok. But of course it's not ok. Not by a mile. Hazel takes a moment to look at him, touches his cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm just... I'm very fond of you. He grabs her hand and holds it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't suppose you can forget about it, treat me like I'm not dying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think you're dying, Augustus. You've just got a touch of cancer. Gus nods. Squeezes her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would it be absolutely ludicrous to make out right now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Hazel doesn't answer. She just kisses him, hard. And on the two of them, so in love, we CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel lays on Gus's shoulder as he stares out the window, leaving Amsterdam behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - BAGGAGE CLAIM - DAY As they ride down the escalator, Hazel sees Michael standing amongst the livery drivers. He holds a sign that says - instead of someone's last name - "My Beautiful Family (and Gus)." Upon seeing them, he immediately starts to cry of course. He kisses his wife, gives Hazel a big hug. Gus goes to shake his hand but Michael hugs him as well. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel sits with her father on the couch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gus had a recurrence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Waters told us the night before you left. (BEAT) I'm sorry Hazel. They sit for a beat. Tears form in Michael's eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not gonna say it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The usual. "Everything happens for a reason..." Michael shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know, Haze. (BEAT) I always thought being an adult meant knowing what you believe... (BEAT) ... that has not been my experience. Hazel understands exactly. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gus lays in bed, eyes open, a PICC line now being fed through a port in his chest. Chemotherapy at work. Hazel and Isaac are keeping him company.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How are your eyes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great. Wonderful. I mean, they're not in my head is the only problem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hate to one-up you but... seems my entire body is made out of cancer now, so... Isaac nods. Tries not to get emotional but it's happening. He goes to touch Gus's arm and accidentally touches his thigh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoa, I'm taken. Isaac laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Hazel, re: Gus) Did you write his eulogy yet? Hazel is confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I haven't asked her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. (BEAT) Oops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you talking about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My bad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Augustus? Gus looks at her, grows a little serious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need speakers at my funeral. I thought maybe you and Isaac... but especially you -- ISAAC Hey!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you be kind enough to whip something up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (touches his hand) It would be an honor. They hold holds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You guys are adorable. Hazel play slaps Isaac on the arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's your love life? Anything from Monica?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not a word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hasn't even like, texted to ask how you're doing? He shakes his head. Gus gets an angry look on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is so messed up!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've stopped thinking about it. Moving on. There's a new girl in Support Group with these humongous - Isaac gestures to his chest. Hazel is confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you even know that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm blind but I'm not that blind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel Grace! They turn to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you happen to have four dollars?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . No one knows what that means. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gus is in the passenger's seat. Isaac sits in the back. Hazel returns to the car. With a CARTON OF EGGS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ok now what? Gus smiles. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel, Gus, and Isaac lean against Hazel's car staring something down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh it's there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: they're looking at Monica's green Firebird.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's in the house?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who cares where she is? This is not about her. This is about you. (sticks out his hand) Hazel... Hazel nods, opens the egg carton, hands Gus an egg. Gus puts it in Isaac's hands. Positions Isaac - who, of course, can't see a thing - towards the Firebird. Isaac winds up and tosses the EGG. It misses the car by a mile. After a beat:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't hear anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A little to the left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My throw was to the left or I should aim to the left?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aim left. Isaac turns his shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lefter. Isaac turns some more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes! Excellent! And throw hard. Gus hands him a SECOND EGG. Isaac winds up and hurls it - missing the car again but hitting the HOUSE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bullseye!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No you missed it by like 20 feet. (hands him a THIRD) Try one more time. Isaac hurls it, this time smashing the car's taillight. Isaac's face lights up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Woo hoo! Isaac grabs for ANOTHER EGG. Throws it. Then ANOTHER. He's a throwing machine. Most of them miss but at least he's enjoying himself. Finally there's a DIRECT HIT on the car door, triggering the alarm. Isaac pauses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keep throwing, keep throwing! Isaac does. Gus smiles, putting an unlit cigarette in his mouth. Hazel watches him, enjoying this moment. Eventually, MONICA'S MOM opens the front door and comes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What in God's name -- Seeing Hazel, Gus, and Isaac, she stops in her tracks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you Monica's mom?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello ma'am. Your daughter has done an injustice and we've come here seeking revenge. We may not look like much. Between the three of us, we have five legs, four eyes, and two and a half working lungs. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But we also have two dozen eggs. So If I was you, I would go back inside. Monica's Mom is very confused. A beat. Without another word, she turns and goes back inside. The three of them celebrate. As Isaac picks up where he left off, Hazel gently kisses Gus on the cheek. And over we hear:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) A few days later, Gus landed in the hospital with chest pains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - WAITING ROOM - DAY Hazel bounds in to find Mrs. Waters in the waiting room. She stands to hug Hazel. They both sit down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's he doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WATERS He's had a tough night, Hazel. His blood pressure's low. His heart -- Mrs. Waters starts to cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about the chemo?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WATERS (shakes her head) They're gonna stop the chemo. They both know what that means. Mrs. Waters gathers herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I see him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WATERS (BEAT) We have to be a family now. Hazel nods. She understands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WATERS We'll tell him you were here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you don't mind, I'll just hang for a while. Mrs. Waters nods, hugs her again, walks out through the heavy doors towards Gus's room. Hazel sits in the chair. Same chair Gus sat in while waiting for her. They've switched places.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel pushes Gus, now confined to a WHEELCHAIR, to their spot on the hill overlooking "Funky Bones." A second picnic, this time with champagne. Hazel pours some for them both into little Winnie the Pooh cups. She's trying to be upbeat - but it's difficult. Gus watches the kids play on the bones.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you thinking about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oblivion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Augustus...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know it's kid's stuff but... I always thought I'd have a grand story to tell, you know? Something that would run in all the papers. I always thought I was special.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah but... you know what I mean. Hazel, annoyed finishes her cup, tosses it to the side. Gus can tell he's said something wrong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do know what you mean, I just... I don't agree. Hazel stands up, anger building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This obsession with being
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't get mad -- HAZEL But I am mad! (BEAT) I think you're special, is that not enough?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think the only way to live a meaningful life is for everyone to love you, for everyone to remember you. Well guess what, Gus, this is your life. This is all you get. You get me, and your family, and this world. And if that's not enough, well I'm sorry, but it's not nothing. Cause I'll remember you, I'll love you -- GUS You're right -- HAZEL And I just wish... I just wish you'd be happy with that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right. I'm sorry. (pulling her back down) I'm sorry. Gus hands Hazel another Winnie the Pooh cup. Raises his to hers in a toast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a good life, Hazel Grace. She softens. They toast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not over yet, you know. Gus nods. Of course it isn't. And yet they both know there isn't much time. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel is asleep. Suddenly, her phone buzzes. She looks at it - "Gus" - then she looks at the clock - 2:35am. A pit grows in her stomach. A quick panicked beat before she answers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) (WEAKLY) Hazel Grace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, thank God. Hi. Hi, I love you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) I'm at the gas station -- 94.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Something's wrong. You gotta... please come help me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel drives like a maniac down the street, eventually finding herself at the Speedway gas station. Gus's car is alone in the parking lot and she pulls up next to it. She gets out of her car, opens his driver's side door, and finds him sitting there, his shirt stained with vomit and blood. She gags from the smell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi. Hazel looks down at his hands which are pressed tightly to his belly. She sees something is leaking from the TUBE sticking out of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, God, Augustus, I'm calling 911.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! Please! Hazel, listen to me. Do not call 911 or my parents -- I'll never forgive you -- Don't, please. Gus starts to cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please just look at it. Hazel lifts up his shirt. His ABDOMEN is bright red.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think it's infected... Hazel feels his forehead, he's burning up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gus, what the -- why are you here? Why aren't you home? Gus throws up. He doesn't even have the energy to turn his mouth away from his lap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, sweetie...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted to buy some cigarettes. I lost my pack. Or they took it. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. They said they'd get me another one but I wanted... to do it myself. Do one little thing myself. Hazel doesn't know what to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't fix this. I have to call someone. I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Hazel, please! But she must. She gets out her cell phone and dials. At which point, Gus really loses it, weeping like the poisoned, dying teenage boy that he is. As Hazel dials, we hear:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) I wish I could say Augustus Waters kept his sense of humor till the end, did not for a moment waiver in his courage and his spirit soared like an eagle to the sky...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to himself, shaking) I hate myself I hate myself I hate this I hate this...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) ...but that is not what happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . An EMT loads Gus into the back of an AMBULANCE. Hazel is allowed to ride with him in the back. As the car starts moving, Gus grabs her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Read me something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Read you something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know any poems?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Read it to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "The Red Wheelbarrow" by William Carlos Williams. (beat, tries to remember) "So much depends / upon / a red wheel / barrow / glazed with rain / water / beside the white / chickens."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that it? That is it. But there's another ten minutes of driving to do. Hazel thinks fast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No of course not. Um... what else... (THINKS) so much depends/ upon a blue sky/ cut open by the branches/ of the trees./ So much depends/ on the transparent G-tube/ erupting from the belly/ of the blue-lipped boy. Gus smiles, weakly, barely conscious. Hazel cradles his head in her arms. And continues...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So much depends upon this observer/ of the universe... As Gus is drifting off to sleep, WE HEAR:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) One of the less bull-shitty conventions of the cancer genre is the convention known as the "Last Good Day..."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gus comes home from the hospital. He does not look good - but he lives. Hazel is there to help get him inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gus no longer sleeps in his basement. Nor does he sleep in his own bed. He sleeps in a HOSPITAL BED set up in a guest room. Hazel is with him. They're watching sports on TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) This is where the victim of cancer finds himself unexpectedly with some hours...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel and Gus getting some fresh air. She sits there reading a book. Gus just sits there. His eyes staring off into nothing. Hazel waves to him. Gus looks over, as if waking from a dream. She manages a smile. He manages one back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) ... when it seems like the inexorable decline has suddenly plateaued, when the pain is for a minute bearable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel sits at dinner with her parents. She is barely touching her food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) The problem, of course, is that there's no way of knowing that your last good day is your "Last Good Day." At the time, it's just another decent day. The phone buzzes and Hazel answers it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Augustus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Good evening, Hazel Grace. His voice is strong today, and Hazel is happy to hear it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Quick question for you. Did you ever write that eulogy I asked you to prepare?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I may have...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excellent. Do you think you could find yourself at the Literal Heart of Jesus in 20 minutes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Um... sure. Is everything -- GUS (O.S.) I love you Hazel. The call ends. Hazel, confused, stands to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gotta go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finish eating first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't, I have to meet Gus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You haven't eaten a thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not hungry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't not eat, Hazel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am aggressively unhungry, ok?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel, listen to your mother. Hazel tries to push past her but Frannie grabs her shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have to eat, Hazel. You're not gonna starve yourself to death just because Gus is sick. You have to stay healthy -- HAZEL I can't! I can't stay healthy because I'm not healthy, Mom. I am dying. I am going to die and leave you here alone and you won't have me to hover around and you won't be a mother anymore, and I'm sorry, but I can't do anything about it, ok?! Just leave me alone! Upon seeing her mother's face change, Hazel immediately regrets this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard me? Frannie has tears in her eyes. Hazel looks away, feeling terrible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard me say that to your father? Frannie sits down on the couch with her daughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh god, sweetie. I'm sorry. I was wrong, ok? It wasn't true. It's not something I believe. Michael sits across from them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As long as either of us is alive, I will be your mother. Even if you die, I -- HAZEL When.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Even when you die, I will still be your mother. I will always be your Mother. By now Michael is crying too. They all are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I worry that you won't have a life. That you'll sit around all day with no me to look after and stare at the walls and be miserable or off yourselves or something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're not gonna off ourselves. It's gonna hurt like hell to lose you
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel. You of all people know it's possible to live with pain. She takes that in. It rings true to her. Hazel nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't just sit around, you know. Hazel is confused. Frannie looks at Michael like, "should I say something?" She goes for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm taking some classes. Online. To get my master's in social work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are? Hazel is stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So when you're waiting for me outside Support Group or whatever, you're always -- 100.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Working or reading. If I get my
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can council families in crisis or lead groups dealing with
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why didn't you tell me? Frannie and Michael don't quite know what to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We didn't want you to feel
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you kidding? Mom, this is awesome! This is fantastic! Oh my god! Hazel grabs her Mom for a hug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so excited! You're gonna be so great, Mom!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. That means everything to me. Mom and Daughter hug. And when it's over:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd still really like you to eat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know Mom. And I will. I promise. But right now... I really gotta go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel enters the Literal Heart of Jesus room which is now empty except for Isaac, up on a dais, and Gus, in his wheelchair. Gus is thinner than we've ever seen him, thinner than any young man should be. But for now, he's happy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel Grace, you look ravishing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know, right? (BEAT) So, um, what's going on guys?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Late for what exactly?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Gus gestures for her to sit next to him and she does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted to attend my funeral. By the way, will you speak at my funeral? Hazel looks at him like "of course, silly" and then kisses him on the mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sweet. I'm hopeful I'll get to attend as a ghost, but just to make sure, I thought I'd - well, not to put you on the spot, but I thought I'd arrange a pre-funeral.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No time like the present.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looks around the room) How did you even get in here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you believe they leave the door open at night?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Um, no.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As well you shouldn't. He smiles and for a brief moment it's old Gus. Hazel laughs. Isaac clears his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Augustus Waters was a self- aggrandizing bastard. But we forgive him. We forgive him... not because he had a heart as figuratively good as his actual one sucked, or because he got 18 years when he should have gotten more."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm assuming you've got some time, you interrupting bastard! I mean seriously... (back to the speech) "Augustus Waters talked so much that he'd interrupt you at his own funeral. And he was pretentious. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sweet Jesus that kid never took a piss without pondering the resonances of human waste production. And he was vain. But that comes with superhuman handsomeness." Gus nods - that part is true.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "But I will say this: when the scientists of the future show up at my house with robot eyes and they tell me to try them on, I will tell the scientists to piss off, because I don't even want to see a world without Augustus Waters." Hazel smiles - but it's one that triggers an immediate emotional waterfall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "And then, of course, having made my rhetorical point, I will put my robot eyes on because, I mean... robot eyes!" Gus has a big smile on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "So anyway, Augustus, my friend... Godspeed." Gus nods a couple times.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you Isaac. This causes Isaac to lose it. He clings to the lectern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goddamn it, Gus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey don't swear in the Literal Heart of Jesus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit! Ass! Balls! Isaac sighs. Wipes away the tears. And another beat passes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I get a hand here, Hazel? Hazel remembers Isaac can't see. She rises, goes up to get him, walks him back to her seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel Grace, it's down to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Hazel takes out a piece of paper, walks up to the dais. Takes a beat to ready herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Augustus Waters was the great star- crossed love of my life. Ours was an epic love story, and I won't be able to get more than a sentence into it without disappearing into a puddle of tears. (BEAT) Like all real love stories - ours will die with us, as it should. I'd hoped that he'd be eulogizing me, because there's no one I'd rather have..." And that's all she can get out before falling apart. She lets it out for a couple beats and then pulls herself together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (beat, composing herself)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: can't talk about our love story so instead I will talk about math. I am not a mathematician, but I know this: there are infinite numbers between 0 and 1. There's .1 And .12 And .112 And an infinite collection of others. Of course, there is a bigger infinite set of numbers between 0 and 2, or between 0 and a million. Some infinities are bigger than other infinities. A writer we used to like taught us that. I want more numbers than I'm likely to get, and God, I want more numbers for Augustus Waters than he got. But, Gus, my love, I cannot tell you how thankful I am for our little infinity. You gave me a forever within the numbered days, and for that I am eternally grateful. I love you." Gus smiles, nods, and closes his eyes. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Over which we hear a RINGING TELEPHONE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel turns on the LIGHT by her bed. Her HOUSE PHONE is ringing and it's 4am. She knows instantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Augustus Waters died eight days later in the ICU... Hazel's head falls into her chest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) ... when the cancer, which was made of him, stopped his heart, which was also made of him. Her bedroom door opens. It's Frannie and Michael. This only confirms her worst fears. She starts to cry. Her parents embrace her in the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) It was unbearable. The whole thing. Every second worse than the last.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - DRIVEWAY - SAME Hazel sits in the car in the dark. She's blaring the loudest music she can possibly blare - a means of drowning out the horrors of the world. Over which we hear this:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) One of the first things they ask you in the ER is to rate your pain on a scale from 1 to 10. I'd been asked this question hundreds of times and I remember once, early on, when I couldn't catch my breath and it felt like my chest was on fire, and the nurse asked me to rate the pain and though I couldn't speak, I held up 9 fingers. The loud music isn't protecting Hazel as well as she hoped. She falls apart nonetheless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Later on, when I'd been feeling better, the nurse came in and she called me a fighter. "You know how I know," she said. "Because you called a ten a nine."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel puts on her funeral dress. She looks in the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) But that wasn't the truth. The reason I called it a nine was... I was saving my ten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The place is filled today with mourners for Augustus Waters. Hazel comes in with her parents and stands in the back, watching people she's never seen before approach the Waters family and extend their deepest condolences.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) And this was it. The great and terrible ten. When Mr. and Mrs. Waters see Hazel, they open their arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WATERS He loved you so much. Hazel nods. Hugs them back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He loved you so much too. More MOURNERS approach the family, leaving Hazel stranded in the receiving line. Her eyes turn towards the COFFIN. She's not entirely sure she wants to go there but she takes a deep breath, wills herself to walk towards it. Gus is there in the same suit he wore to Oranjee. Immediately, Hazel breaks down. And immediately, she catches herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's ok, you hear me? It's ok. She leans forward and kisses his cheek. She looks around. Once in the clear, she pulls out a hard pack of Camel Lights and sticks them in the space between Gus and the lining of the coffin. A MINISTER approaches at that moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think we're ready to begin. Hazel nods and walks back to her parents, taking her seat in the middle of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Augustus Waters fought hard for many years. His battle was a courageous one and his strength was a source of inspiration for each and every one of us... Hazel frowns. This is all such bullshit. And she hears:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a load of shit, eh kid? Hazel recognizes that voice. But it doesn't make sense. She turns around and, sure enough, it's Peter Van Houten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let us pray. Everyone clasps their hands, closes their eyes. Hazel keeps staring at Van Houten, too shocked to do a thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We need to fake pray now. Van Houten bows his head. Hazel, still stunned, slowly turns back to the Minister, trying to make sense of this unexpected appearance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now I call on Augustus's close friend Isaac to say a few words. Isaac stands, walks up to the podium with someone's help. Hazel sneaks one more look at Van Houten. Yup, it's really him. That makes no sense to her. Isaac starts to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of all the things I've lost in my life, this hurts the most. And Isaac stops talking. It's unclear if that was the end or if he just can't go on. He returns to his seat. The Minister walks back up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now we'll hear from Gus's... special friend Hazel Lancaster. Hazel stands, walks up to the podium. A few titters in the room at the words "special friend."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was his girlfriend. Some laughter from the crowd. She takes out her notes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a beautiful quote in Gus's home that reads "if you want the rainbow, you gotta deal with the rain." Hazel continues to speak but we over it, WE HEAR instead:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) I didn't believe a word, of course. But that was ok. Funerals, I'd decided, aren't for the dead. They're for the living. Gus's Parents, arm in arm, nod along with every word. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone is watching Gus's body be lowered into the ground. Everyone but Hazel. She looks off into the distance. Off to the side, we see Van Houten, also not watching the burial. He's watching Hazel. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Ceremony over, we see Hazel with her parents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you sure? We can drive you -- HAZEL No, I'd... I'd like to be alone for a while. Hazel hugs Mom and Dad, walks alone towards the parking lot. As she gets to the car, Van Houten approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could I hitch a ride? Hazel doesn't want to help this man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just to the bottom of the hill. Hazel exhales. Fine. Once they're both in the car:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did you even -- VAN HOUTEN The internet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you just... bought a ticket?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The drinks are free drinks in First Class. Van Houten removes a FLASK from his coat pocket. Takes a swig. Hazel shakes her head in disgust. Starts driving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Omnis Cellula e cellula. Hazel ignores him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your boy Waters and I corresponded quite a bit in his last -- HAZEL You read your fan mail now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would hardly call him a fan. He despised me. But he was quite insistent I attend his funeral and tell you what became of Anna and her mother. So here I am and that's your answer: omnis cellula e cellula.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so not in the mood -- VAN HOUTEN "Life comes from life."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodbye Mr. Van Houten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't want an explanation?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nope. Thanks though. Have a great life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You remind me of her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I remind a lot of people of a lot of people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was eight, my daughter. She suffered... beautifully. For so long. Hazel starts to understand Van Houten - and softens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She had leukemia? Like Anna?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just like her, yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Were you married then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not when she died, no. I was insufferable long before Anna, my dear. Grief doesn't change you, Hazel, it reveals you. Hazel takes that in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well I'm sorry for your loss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'm sorry for yours. I'm sorry for everything, for being so rude to you two, for ruining your trip -- HAZEL You didn't ruin our trip, you asshole. We had an awesome trip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel, I'm trying. I'm trying! You asked me to tell you what happens and I wish I could do that. I wish that I could. But I can't. No one can. No one knows, Hazel. They don't talk to us. Unless... Van Houten takes out a typed piece of paper. He hands it to Hazel who grabs it - and immediately crumples it into a ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think I care about that? I don't give a shit, Van Houten. Hazel throws the piece of paper at Van Houten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a drunk and a jerk and a failure. And I'd like you to get out of my car right now so I can go home and grieve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get out of the car! Van Houten knows he's too late. He does as he's told, stepping out of the car onto the side of the road. He stands there as Hazel peels out. In the rearview mirror, she sees him raise the FLASK, as if toasting her. She blinks away some tears and drives. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel lies in front of the TV. "Top Model" is playing but she's lost in her own world. Tears fall from her eyes and she can't do anything to stop it. Hazel gets up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - CONTINUOUS Hazel sits against the tub on the floor and weeps. Soon there's a knock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Occupada.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Can I come in? Hazel leans over and unlocks the door. Michael kneels down next to her, putting her head on his shoulder. Hazel presses her face into his shirt and cries some more. Michael squeezes her tightly. And this time, he doesn't cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so so sorry. (BEAT) It was a privilege to love him, though, wasn't it? Hazel nods into his shirt. Then looks up at her Dad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gives you an idea how we feel about you. Michael smiles at Hazel. And he doesn't cry. Hazel draws strength from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel and Isaac have climbed through his open bedroom window. They sit on the roof.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know if it hurt or whatever?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was really fighting for breath, I guess. He eventually went unconscious, but it seems like, yeah, it wasn't great or anything. Dying sucks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It just seems so impossible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Happens all the time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you angry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me too. (a few beats) Gus really loved you, you know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wouldn't shut up about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was annoying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't find it that annoying. They sit there in silence a few beats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you read the note or whatever from your author friend?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is not my friend and -- how do you know about that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We talked at the cemetery. Said he came all this way to give you that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah well I'm over it. I never want to read another word of that asshole's again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah but he didn't write it - Gus did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what he said. Gus had written something, sent it to Van
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel sits up. Her heart is racing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I have to go. I... Are you...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do it all the time. Go. As quickly as possible Hazel leaves. Isaac stays behind, enjoying the cool night. A new day is coming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hazel is inside the car, rummaging crazily through the trash in an effort to find what Van Houten gave her. She's about to give up when she sees it - crumpled up into a ball beneath the passenger's seat. She reaches under, pulls it up, and unwraps it. As she reads, WE HEAR:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Van Houten, I'm a good person but a shitty writer. You're a shitty person but a good writer. We'd make a good team. I don't want to ask you any favors but if you have the time, and from what I saw you have plenty, please fix this for me. It's a eulogy for Hazel. Hazel is overcome with emotion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She asked me to write one and I'm trying, I just, I could use a little flair. See the thing is... we all want to be remembered. She smiles to herself, remembering: - That first time Gus and Hazel ran into each other. - The staring contest in Support Group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We all want to leave a mark. - Driving (badly) in Gus's car. - Their first kiss at the picnic by "Funky Bones."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But not Hazel. Hazel is different. Hazel knows the truth. She didn't want a million admirers, she just wanted one. And she got it. Maybe she wasn't loved widely but she was loved deeply. And isn't that more than most of us get? - And BACK TO HAZEL reading the letter, tears in her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When Hazel was sick, I knew I was dying. But I didn't want to say so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FLASHBACK Gus stealthily sneaks into Hazel's single room in the ICU. She sleeps. He kneels by her side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was in ICU and I snuck in for ten minutes and sat with her before I got caught. Her eyes were closed, her lungs were intubated... Gus takes her hand and holds it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... but her hands were still her hands, still warm, and the nails painted this dark blue back color and I just held her hands and I willed myself to imagine a world without us and what a worthless world that would be. - AND BACK TO HAZEL reading the letter. She never knew that story, never knew he was there. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - BACKYARD - LATER Hazel walks out to the grass behind her house, the oxygen tank dragging behind her. She lays down on the grass and looks up at the stars - the same IMAGE that opened the movie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's so beautiful. You don't get tired of looking at her. You never worry if she's smarter than you cause you know she is. She's funny without ever being mean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - The magical dinner at Oranjee. - The bench in which they sat overlooking the water. - The passionate kiss in Anne Frank's house. - Falling onto the bed together. [All of these are images we saw at the beginning of the movie, only now, we SEE the oxygen tank, we SEE Gus's leg, we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the fumbling and the difficulties etc. They don't make these images less beautiful. They make them twice as beautiful - because they're real.]
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love her, god I love her. I'm so lucky to love her, Van Houten. (MORE)
direction.name: direction
